Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there is evidence of transmission of COVID-19 from humans to animals, including cats and ferrets.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it is not backed by any official statement from the WHO.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that cats and dogs cannot carry COVID-19 based on the absence of ACE2 in their bodies, which is a problematic assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The alternative explanation is that while cats and dogs can get infected with COVID-19, there is limited evidence of them transmitting the virus to humans.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the idea that cats and dogs will not become organisms carrying COVID-19, when there is evidence of transmission at the human-animal interface.
Understate: There is no understatement bias in this claim.
Falters at times: The claim falters by misrepresenting the WHO's position on the issue and falsely attributing a statement to them.
